title: Ms. Joyce Msuya, Acting Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator - Remarks during the High-Level Side Event at the 79th Session of the General Assembly (25 September 2024) - Sudan | ReliefWeb 
 content: “The Cost of Inaction: Urgent and Collective Support to Scale Up the Humanitarian Response in Sudan and the Region”
New York, 25 September 2024
As delivered
I want to start by thanking all our co-hosts here on the panel for partnering with the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs to convene this hugely important and urgent event.
Thank you to our young Sudanese climate and peace activist, Ms. Nisreen Elsaim, for participating to give her testimony.
And thank you to all for attending.
Excellencies, this time last year, we gathered in an almost identical meeting.
We warned of a humanitarian crisis of epic proportions in Sudan – one that threatened to deteriorate into a catastrophe without urgent international action.
The nightmare that has since unfolded has exceeded our worst fears.
The people of Sudan continue to pay the unbearable price of a war in which horrific violations continue unabated:
Civilians killed in their hundreds in attacks on residential areas.
Sexual violence used as a tactic of war, particularly against women and girls.
Ethnically motivated attacks, and testimonies of summary execution, rape and forced displacement in West Darfur.
And now, as the rainy season and its devastating floods subside, we have seen a rapid escalation of the fighting in El Fasher in North Darfur, causing further death and destruction, with clashes also continuing to directly impact civilians in several other areas.
The humanitarian situation in Sudan is beyond appalling.
The war has triggered what is now among the world’s largest displacement crises.
More than half the population of Sudan – 25.6 million people – is acutely food insecure.
Last month, famine was confirmed in Zamzam displacement camp, near El Fasher, with similar conditions likely in nearby sites, and many other areas at immediate risk.
Almost 5 million children under the age of 5 and pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers are already acutely malnourished.
And basic services – including healthcare, schools, water and sanitation systems and life-saving telecommunications networks – have largely broken down.
This dire situation is compounded by severe constraints on humanitarian access:
A volatile security situation that complicates the movement of supplies and endangers humanitarian personnel.
A wide range of bureaucratic and administrative restrictions that can further delay aid deliveries and the movement of humanitarian personnel.
Frequent denials of access to key areas.
And, over recent months, heavy rains that have damaged roads, bridges and a crucial dam, and enabled the rapid spread of cholera and other diseases.
Despite the courageous efforts of local and international humanitarian organizations, we simply cannot deliver adequate levels of assistance.
Let us not be here again, in one year’s time, lamenting another 12 months of death, destruction and unbearable suffering.
Today, let us commit to taking urgent, concrete steps to protect and support civilians in Sudan.
First, we urge Member States to use all their leverage to bring the horrific violations of international humanitarian law and the abuses of human rights law to an end.
Second, we need a concerted diplomatic push for a step change in humanitarian access.
For the safe, streamlined and swift delivery of aid through all possible routes – both cross-border and cross-line.
And for the facilitation of the day-to-day life-saving work of humanitarian organizations on the ground.
We welcome the recent announcement by the President of the Sovereign Council of Sudan to reopen the crucial Adre crossing from Chad.

title: Sudan: Pregnant Women and Children Dying in Shocking Numbers in South Darfur 
 content: One of the worst maternal and child health emergencies in the world is unfolding in South Darfur, Sudan, according to a report released by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). Pregnant, birthing, and postpartum women, as well as children, are dying from preventable conditions as their health needs far exceed what MSF can respond to.
Driven to oblivion: the toll of conflict and neglect on the health of mothers and children in South Darfur reveals the number of maternal deaths in just two MSF-supported hospitals in South Darfur between January and August to be more than seven per cent of the total number of maternal deaths in all MSF facilities worldwide in 2023. A screening of children for malnutrition also found rates well beyond emergency thresholds.
Driven to oblivion: the toll of conflict and neglect on the health of mothers and children in South Darfur pdf -- 9.75 MB Download
For these crises to be addressed, the United Nations (UN) must act decisively to prevent further loss of life in Darfur. The UN must accelerate the return of UN staff and agencies to Darfur and leverage all available resources and political influence to ensure that aid reaches those in need. Only a coordinated international response, supported by robust funding and unyielding pressure on the warring parties, can avert mass starvation and alleviate the suffering of millions.
"This is a crisis unlike any other I have seen in my career," says Dr Gillian Burkhardt, MSF sexual and reproductive health activity manager speaking in Nyala, South Darfur. "Multiple health emergencies are happening simultaneously with almost no international response from the UN and others. Newborn babies, pregnant women, and new mothers are dying in shocking numbers. And so many of these deaths are due to preventable conditions, but almost everything has broken down."
From January to August in South Darfur, there were 46 maternal deaths in Nyala Teaching and Kas Rural hospitals, where MSF teams provide obstetric care and other services. The scarcity of functioning health facilities and unaffordable transportation costs mean many women arrive at hospital in critical condition. Around 78 per cent of these 46 deaths occurred in the first 24 hours following admission.
Sepsis was the most common cause of maternal death in all MSF-supported facilities in South Darfur. The dearth of functioning health facilities forces women to give birth in unsanitary environments that lack basic items such as soap, clean delivery mats, and sterilised instruments. Without these basic items women are getting infections. And with antibiotics in low supply, they can arrive at a hospital only to be met with no treatment option available.
"A pregnant patient from a rural area waited two days to collect the money needed to get care," says Maria Fix, MSF medical team leader in South Darfur. "When she travelled to a health centre, they had no drugs, so she went back home."
"After three days, her condition deteriorated but again she had to wait five hours for transportation. She was already in a coma when she reached us," says Fix. "She died from a preventable infection."
The crisis in South Darfur extends to children, with thousands on the brink of death and starvation, while others are dying of preventable conditions. From January to June 2024, 48 newborns died from sepsis in in Nyala Teaching and Kas Rural hospitals, meaning one in five newborns with sepsis did not survive.
So many of these deaths are due to preventable conditions. Dr Gillian Burkhardt, MSF sexual and reproductive health activity manager speaking in Nyala
Share this
In August, 30,000 children under two-years-old were screened for malnutrition in South Darfur. Of these, 32.5% were found to be acutely malnourished, well beyond the World Health Organization's emergency threshold of 15%. Furthermore, 8.1% of children screened were severely acutely malnourished.
Nyala, the capital of South Darfur, was a hub for humanitarian organisations before the war. But since its outbreak, most organisations have not returned. The UN still has no international staff in the city, where MSF is one of the only international organisations present. Between January and August, MSF teams in South Darfur provided 12,600 ante- and post-natal consultations and assisted in 4,330 normal and complicated deliveries.
Across Sudan, interrelated crises are compounding to cause immense suffering, with little help available, as Dr Burkhardt, who worked in North Darfur prior to her assignment in South Darfur, explains.
"The disparity between the huge needs for healthcare, food, and basic services, and the consistently lacking international response is disgraceful," she says. "We call on donors, the UN, and international organisations to urgently increase funding for, as well as scale up and supply, maternal health and nutrition programmes."
We call on donors, the UN, and international organisations to urgently increase funding for, as well as scale up and supply, maternal health and nutrition programmes. Dr Burkhardt, MSF sexual and reproductive health activity manager speaking in Nyala
Share this
"We know that Sudan is a challenging place to work but waiting for challenges to disappear by themselves is getting nowhere," says Dr Burkhardt. "For many mothers and children, it's already too late. Risks must be managed, and solutions found before more lives are lost."
Conflict is also driving the maternal and child health crisis as people are displaced and subject to violence. Supply shortages are aggravated by the warring parties which, along with their affiliated armed groups, continue to block or restrict access to lifesaving aid.
The crisis risks trapping families in protracted cycles of malnutrition, sickness, and deteriorating health that span generations.
A patient caretaker describes how maternal mortality and malnutrition are interrelated for their family.
"The mother of the twins died from severe bleeding, leaving behind eight other children," they say. "My husband and I try to take care of them... we don't earn enough to feed them. Now we're 13 in the house. We're struggling, eating porridge and sauce with a bit of salt, little or no oil, and green leaves."

title: When Will It Be Enough? Humanitarian organizations call for urgent action from World Leaders as the people of Sudan face unprecedented starvation and violence [EN/AR] - Sudan | ReliefWeb 
 content: Nairobi, Sept 23, 2024 – Ahead of the Ministerial Meeting on Sudan at this year’s UN General Assembly (UNGA), members of the Sudan NGO Forum call on the international community to increase pressure on conflict parties to facilitate immediate humanitarian access through all possible cross border and cross-line routes; establish mechanisms to protect civilians and essential infrastructure from indiscriminate attacks; and increase funding and initiatives to support communities’ responding at scale to this crisis.
Sudan is experiencing a man-made starvation crisis of historic proportions, largely driven by the actions and decisions of the conflict parties, in violation of international humanitarian law (IHL).
As of August 2024, over 25 million people across Sudan are facing severe acute food insecurity, and at least 755,000 people facing catastrophic (IPC Phase 5) levels of hunger could die in the coming months without urgent and decisive action from the international community. Over 10 million people have fled their homes since the conflict broke out in April 2023, making Sudan the world’s largest internal displacement crisis, affecting more than 5 million children, and over 2 million people, who have crossed into neighboring countries.
While famine has been confirmed in Zamzam camp in North Darfur, the Famine Review Committee affirm that thousands more people are likely experiencing similar conditions in 13 other areas at risk of famine, including Darfur, Kordofan, Al Jazirah and Khartoum. Humanitarian organizations' experience already shows that children are dying every single day due to malnutrition, with some health facilities reporting five daily deaths.
The crisis is primarily the result of systematic and indiscriminate attacks by all conflict parties on civilians, particularly local responders delivering assistance in the hardest to reach areas. Hospitals, schools, markets, telecommunications, water and irrigation systems and other infrastructure essential to people's survival have also been targeted, as documented by the UN Fact-Finding Mission for the Sudan.
In El Fasher, the largest city in the Darfur region, civilians have been living under siege since May 2024, with the UN Special Adviser of the Secretary-General on the Prevention of Genocide warning that indicators of genocide could exist. This past week has seen a further escalation of hostilities, including shelling and aerial bombardment, putting the lives of over 1.5 million civilians at risk.
The conflict's impact is exacerbated by ongoing severe restrictions on civilian access to life-saving supplies such as food, cash, medicine, water and fuel. Despite commitments to the contrary by parties to the conflict, restrictions on civilian movement and limitations on the movement of essential humanitarian supplies and personnel across borders and lines of conflict, are preventing humanitarian aid from being delivered at scale. Between August and September 2024, nearly 7 million people could not access humanitarian assistance due to access constraints, including arbitrary denials. Many communities in the states of South Kordofan,
Khartoum, Al-Jazirah, Central Darfur and Blue Nile are being completely cut off from aid.
As delegates meet at UNGA this week, Member States should urgently act on the findings of the UN Fact-Finding Mission on Sudan and take tangible steps to protect civilians from the impacts of the conflict, safeguard access to principled humanitarian assistance, at a scale which meets their urgent needs and ensure accountability for violations of IHL. NGOs urge UN Member States engaging on Sudan at UNGA to:
Secure unhindered and unimpeded humanitarian access:
• Apply increased diplomatic pressure on conflict parties—and their backers—to: lift all constraints to aid delivery; facilitate the critical work of humanitarian organizations, including local organizations and mutual aid groups; increase all feasible cross-border and cross-line entry points; and publicly condemn denials of humanitarian access by all parties.
• Pressure the conflict parties to cease the deliberate targeting of aid workers, including local organizations and other community-based mutual aid groups.
Ensure the protection of civilians:
• Spotlight violations against civilians, including grave violations against women and children, committed by the warring parties as well as their backers. Call on conflict parties to immediately cease all actions that endanger civilians and civilian objects and infrastructure, especially those essential to food production and distribution.
• In response to the UNSG’s anticipated report to the UN Security Council on options to protect civilians, take immediate steps to resource and operationalize key recommendations.
• Mandate and resource a dedicated neutral and independent body to champion, lead, and coordinate Protection of Civilians (PoC) efforts, with a primary focus on supporting local level PoC initiatives.
• Recognize, endorse and support localized conflict Early Warning Systems and conflict monitoring to facilitate conflict mediation and de-escalation.
Strengthen diplomacy on conflict-induced hunger:
• The UN Security Council, UN leadership and member states should engage in proactive diplomacy to highlight and condemn the use of hunger as a weapon of war in Sudan, as per Resolution 2417 and the G7 Famine Prevention Compact
• Considering escalating food insecurity, increase the frequency of briefings in the UNSC on conflict-induced hunger in Sudan and mandate the monitoring of the risk of the use of starvation as a tactic of war. This could be supported by a cross-sector reporting mechanism documenting instances of IHL violations leading to hunger, including denials of humanitarian assistance.
Increase flexible funding for all humanitarian action in Sudan:
• Immediately and significantly increase funding to the Sudan humanitarian response to scale up multisectoral humanitarian assistance; including flexible and direct funding to local actors, including women and youth led organizations, who are best placed to help communities in dire need.
The Sudan NGO Forum is the coordination and representation body for the international nongovernmental organization (INGO) community in Sudan. The Forum is currently comprised of 70 members and observer members providing humanitarian and development assistance and peacebuilding interventions across all 18 states of Sudan.

title: How MSF provides mental health care for migrants and asylum seekers at the US-Mexico border 
 content: Clinical social worker Athena Viscusi explains how MSF is responding to the needs of people crossing the border into Arizona and the stories they share about their journeys to the US.
For many people traveling through the Americas in search of safety, crossing the southern border into the United States marks the end of a dangerous and uncertain journey—but the start of another that brings its own challenges.
In August, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) resumed collaboration with local humanitarian organizations in Arizona that assist people crossing the southern US border from Mexico, delivering essentials like hygiene products, food, water, and psychological first aid.
Many migrants describe a flood of emotions and relief for having arrived, but also sadness and anger over the difficulties they have experienced and homesickness for what and who they left behind.
Below, Athena Viscusi, a clinical social worker in MSF’s psychosocial care unit working in Arizona, answers questions about our work with people crossing the border, their needs, and what they tell her about their journeys to the United States.
What are some of the needs that asylum seekers have right after they cross the border into the US?
We talk about post-traumatic stress in people on the move. But for those who are just crossing the border, it’s not post-traumatic. They are still in a kind of traumatic reaction, which is a physical and mental state. And they should be. They are hyper alert, and ready to run at any moment after what many of them have gone through.
At this point, it's important to restore that sense of control and agency. They've been completely disempowered and at the mercy of other people. Some have been brutalized repeatedly. And if not themselves, they have witnessed other people being brutalized. Some have been under a constant threat of violence for days, weeks, or months.
There is also physical exhaustion. Some of them have been sleeping outside or not sleeping at all, traveling on the floor of a car, or just walking for miles. They really have such overwhelming physical needs that need to be fulfilled: food, water, and rest.
How can aid organizations help meet these needs?
The most relevant psychosocial intervention for most arrivals is psychological first aid—that includes meeting their immediate physical needs for food and rest, listening to them, and connecting them with necessary information. The presence of a trained mental health professional allows more targeted interventions and helps people in distress get relief and develop skills.
Some are from extremely deprived circumstances, have little education or possessions, or are from marginalized or oppressed groups in their countries of origin. Often their family units have been disrupted and they may have lost travel companions along the way.
Some of them have been sleeping outside or not sleeping at all, traveling on the floor of a car, or just walking for miles. They really have such overwhelming physical needs that need to be fulfilled: food, water, and rest.
The length of stay in volunteer-run makeshift camps, size of the group, languages spoken, and the severity of needs affect the quantity and quality of psychosocial services that can be provided.
What material items provide the greatest immediate comfort to those arriving?
Often, there is no cell phone connection along the border wall and for many stretches of desert in the Mexico and US sides of the border, so provision of internet is a key psychosocial intervention; it allows migrants to contact their families.
For volunteers who are helping migrants and asylum seekers on the US side, an internet connection facilitates access to websites and phone calls to get information to reassure and orient them—for example, how to locate someone in detention, where to find medical services in the city of destination, educational materials in various languages, and of course, translation apps.
Providing simple recreational activities for children, such as bubbles, balloons, and small toys, is also a useful psychosocial approach. Trained mental health professionals can also address parents’ concerns about their children and provide information about the immigration process ahead.
What are some of the stories you’ve heard from migrants and asylum seekers? How were you able to help?
A young man from Sudan had been wounded during the shelling of his home outside Khartoum, during which his two brothers died in front of his eyes. He still carried shrapnel embedded in his collarbone. He was tearful and spoke of constantly having the image of his dead brothers in his head. This story had a hopeful ending: one of the volunteers was able to connect him with a relative who is a surgeon in nearby Phoenix, who agreed to operate on him pro bono.
We spoke with a Chinese woman who had been forcibly implanted with an intrauterine device (IUD) due to China’s “one child policy” and religious discrimination. She was crying hysterically, and her partner specifically requested psychological help for her.
A Honduran woman fleeing domestic violence with her six-year-old son had visible scars from what looked like machete cuts. We helped her calm down, understand the asylum process, and refocus on the needs of her son.
An unaccompanied minor from Guinea was separated from the group of unrelated adults he had traveled with. He received an explanation of the system for unaccompanied minors and was prepared psychologically for what was ahead. He had been robbed of all his belongings in Mexico and did not have any family or friends to contact in the US.
What mental health challenges do volunteers experience at the border?
Burnout is a significant factor for volunteers doing this hard and sometimes unrewarding work. Volunteers witness tremendous suffering and injustice. They travel long distances over terrible roads to provide assistance in very remote areas, work long hours in the hot sun with no shade, and go long periods without any means of communication. They receive calls about migrants lost in the desert and find wounded people and dead bodies, while lacking resources such as reliable cars or funds for food and other supplies to meet the needs of migrants. Some have been doing this work since the 1980s.
The most significant factor contributing to volunteer resilience is the social support that comes from a community of like-minded people. Some are members of religious communities and are even members of the clergy. Maintaining social bonds is a key psychological need for both volunteers and migrants.
Our work in Arizona
Since early 2024, MSF has worked alongside volunteers from Humane Borders, Samaritans, No More Deaths, and other Arizona-based groups helping asylum seekers and migrants crossing the US-Mexico border in the Sonora desert. Initially, a small team evaluated medical needs in the region and suggested ways to develop capacity and increase services and collaboration. In August 2024, MSF resumed its support to local groups. MSF will consider additional support based on the needs that might arise from a surge in numbers of people crossing the border.

Sudan, conflict

ETC Situation Report #21 Reporting period: 01/09/2024 to 30/09/2024

The Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) was activated on 25 May 2023 to support the humanitarian response following the outbreak of conflict on 15 April 2023. The ETC is led by WFP in Sudan. ETC Situation Reports (SitReps) are produced monthly.

Highlights

The one Gigabit (1GB) ― internet download speed―dedicated undersea cable activated on 21 August is operational and providing reliable internet services in Port Sudan. The cluster is now planning to expand the connectivity services to Kassala, El Gadaref, Kosti, and Damazine.

The ETC is conducting a pilot project across five locations in Port Sudan to leverage the undersea cable. The pilot is scheduled to run for one month.

The ETC's operational reach has been significantly enhanced with government approval for internal flights to Dongola and Kassala, in addition to Port Sudan.

Situation overview

Programming VHF radios for UN women - Location WFP office Port Sudan

The security situation in Sudan remains highly volatile with the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) dominating Darfur and the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) controlling other regions. The situation in Darfur is particularly concerning due to RSF taking control of the area. In addition, Sudan continues to face infrastructural challenges with telecommunications services severely impacted by internet blackouts and power outages.

In September, security incidents were minimal in Port Sudan, and the stability of the telecommunications infrastructure remained intact. However, regions such as Damazine and areas along the northern border continue to face security threats and humanitarian challenges.

National telecommunications infrastructure

Much of Sudan is affected by several internet blackouts which began on 07 February 2024. National telecommunications services have been severely disrupted across the country and telecommunications infrastructure remains compromised. Partial restoration of services by Mobile Network Operators (MNOs)―Zain and Sudani―has provided limited connectivity, however, these are frequently interrupted due to power cuts and infrastructure damage. Consequently, Sudan relies heavily on satellite communication services as a viable option for data connectivity.

In efforts to improve resilience against connectivity issues, discussions with Sudan’s National Telecommunication Corporation (NTC) have led to strategies for importing essential equipment such as radios and network infrastructure in small batches.

Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC)

www.ETCluster.org
---
Page 2 of 4

See the Sudan ICT Profile for more information on national telecommunications infrastructure.

ETC Activities Coordination

The ETC continued its close coordination with local and international actors to ensure the effective deployment and operational readiness of telecommunications infrastructure.

Plans to establish an operational hub near Khartoum have been suspended due to the worsening security situation, the relocation plans are under review by OCHA and UNDSS.

In September, the ETC is coordinating with the Dubai team to import procured equipment due to stock shortages. Delays in receiving import authorization from the NTC have been a challenge, but the ETC aims to complete the first shipment this month, covering three locations.

A planned mission to Darfur in early September was postponed due to heavy rainfall and the discovery of unexploded ordnance (UXOs). The new mission date is tentatively scheduled for mid-September, pending security assessments.

Humanitarian partners can request information, technical advice, and access to services to the ETC through the Sudan.ETC@wfp.org email address. A ticketing system has been established to manage the high volume of requests being received.

Data connectivity

ETC internet connectivity services are provided in five common operational areas—Port Sudan (41 sites), Kassala (17 sites), Kosti (one site using the WFP office premises), Damazine (one site using the WFP office premises), and El Gedaref (one site).

The activation of the undersea cable in Port Sudan marks a major step forward in improving data connectivity, providing services to multiple humanitarian agencies. The ETC will begin allocating the bandwidth to various locations in collaboration with Sudatel. The first location to receive the allocation will be Kassala, followed by El Gedaref. The team will also focus on the northern region, specifically Atbara and Dongola.

The advanced data connectivity kits remain operational in RSF-controlled regions such as Darfur. However, in SAF-controlled areas, strict regulations have restricted the deployment of these services, and further negotiations are required.

In September, the ETC has initiated a one-month pilot project to optimize data connectivity in five key offices: Nergis, Jebel Alsit, UNDSS, WFP, and UNITAMS.

The ETC continues to use advanced connectivity kits, fibre, and VSAT networks to provide data connectivity across Sudan. Security communications

The four Security Operations Centres (SOCs) in Port Sudan, Kassala, El Gedaref, and Damazine are fully operational. The Port Sudan SOC operates 24/7, and there are plans to extend 24/7 operations to the other SOCs. Currently, all SOCs are connected to a remote SOC (RSOC) in Nairobi, but plans are in place to relocate the RSOC to Port Sudan to be closer to the operational needs.

Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC)

www.ETCluster.org

Following discussions with UNDSS in August to finalize the deployment of radio operators and explore how ETC can support the UNDSS SOCs, a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) has been drafted to formalize the transfer of radio operators’ salaries to the ETC budget. This will ensure the continued support of SOCs across key areas.

During the month, the ETC programmed 20 VHF handheld radios for UN Women to boost the safety of humanitarian responders by ensuring reliable and secure communication. Services for communities

The current plan is to expand the ETC operations, particularly in the Darfur regions, where a significant proportion of the population is in urgent need of humanitarian assistance. Plans to roll out services for communities in Port Sudan remain delayed due to equipment shortages.

A mission to Zalingei was planned for 2 September, but it was tentatively rescheduled to 16 September. However, due to ongoing skirmishes across Khartoum and other parts of the country, the mission has been postponed until further notice.

The ETC has purchased US$3 million worth of networking equipment which is currently being prepositioned in Nairobi for deployment to Sudan. A training workshop consisting of five sessions will be conducted in Dubai in October, targeting WFP staff, UN agencies, and NGOs operating in Sudan and neighbouring countries. The primary purpose of the training is to build the capacity of staff to effectively use and implement the new equipment.

UNHAS has secured government approval to operate internal flights beyond Port Sudan, now extending to Dongola and Kassala. This is a significant development for ETC, as it enhances accessibility for humanitarian agencies to more locations, enabling improved staffing and support for critical operations across the country.

Funding

In 2024, the ETC requires US$6.3 million to continue its provision and expansion of shared ICT services across Sudan in support of humanitarian operations.

So far in 2024, only the UK Foreign Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) has allocated GBP 240,385. This contribution means that the ETC is 5% funded out of the required US$6.3 million. Therefore, an additional US$6 million is still required to meet the funding objectives for 2024. The Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) grant and the US Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance (BHA) are fully consumed.

The team is currently using the funds carried over from 2023 mainly IRA funds. However, concerns were raised as these funds are not expected to last until the end of the year. The ETC is calling for supplementary funds to cover this shortfall.

Challenges

Security concerns, restricted travel, and logistical constraints continue to create operational challenges.

In addition, the ETC faces an ongoing challenge in moving equipment between states. The government has introduced a new requirement whereby prior approval must be obtained before moving any Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) www.ETCluster.org

Telecommunications infrastructure, particularly in SAF-controlled regions, faces operational restrictions, limiting the deployment of critical services. Recent flooding and unexploded ordnance in Darfur have further delayed humanitarian operations.

I.

Context Setting

In mid-April 2023, Sudan descended into a major conflict as clashes between the Sudan Armed country. The conflict has led to over 12,000 deaths, extensive damage to infrastructure, and now faces the world’s largest internal and child displacement crisis.2 This includes 2.3 million seeking refuge in neighboring countries and 10.5 million internally displaced, over half of whom Response Plan, 15% of Sudan's population in need (24.8 million people) and targeted (14.7 million people) are persons with disabilities (PWDs) and 5% of the two above mentioned groups exploitation, violence, and abuse.

The conflict has severely impacted access to basic services, leading to interruptions in water, healthcare, banking, electricity, and telecommunications, compounded by frequent looting5. The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) in late 2023 showed escalating food insecurity and malnutrition, particularly in conflict zones.6 An IPC alert in March 2024 emphasized the worsening situation and the looming threat of famine in highly vulnerable regions with worsening projections of looming famine demonstrated in the new IPC report.7 With ongoing conflict, heightened food insecurity and water scarcity, the protection needs of communities will increase, including GBV and sexual exploitation and abuse (SEA). Women, girls, men, and boys, in all their diversity, will have distinct needs in assistance and face different barriers to assistance that must be accounted for in emergency programming. In response, the Sudan Famine Prevention Operational Plan was launched, coordinating efforts across Food Security and Livelihoods, Nutrition, Health, WASH, Education, Shelter and NFI clusters, with a focus on protection, gender equality, disability inclusion, and cross-cutting themes such as accountability to affected communities and protection from sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA).8

II.

Purpose of Integrated Crosscutting Integrated Risk Analysis and Key Cluster Recommendation Guidance

To provide Famine Prevention Plan actors with technical guidance that will support planned humanitarian interventions to assess and mitigate the various intersectional gendered, disability and inclusion, protection risks, and SEA with humanitarian assistance. This document is an asset to the Famine Prevention Plan as it provides actionable recommendations for Clusters and Working Groups under the Famine Prevention Plan. This is intended to be a living guidance document, fine-tuned with granular information from frontline Implementing / programme Partners, literature review and complemented by operational adjustment. These agreed minimum standards are also expected to inform allocations from the Sudan Humanitarian Fund (SHF).

An integrated risk analysis for cross-cutting issues in the Famine Prevention Plan is essential for several reasons:

1. 2.

3. 4.

Comprehensive Understanding: It provides a thorough grasp of the various factors contributing to food insecurity and vulnerability. Interconnectedness of Risks: It identifies and addresses intersectional risks by examining the interconnected nature of cross-cutting issues to promote a protective, gender responsive, inclusive, and participatory response to humanitarian operations in localities identified as priority locations in the Famine Prevention Plan. Coordination: It aligns efforts to address these concerns, ensuring a coherent and effective response while avoiding duplication and maximizing impact. Accountability and Compliance: It shows a commitment to humanitarian principles and standards, demonstrating accountability and compliance.
---
III.

Integrated Risk Analysis9

Accountability to Affected Populations (AAP) is essential to safeguard engagement and interventions, ensuring they are made with a "do no harm" approach and fulfill the diverse needs, capacities, and preferences of the communities. Access to accurate and timely information is often interrupted, leaving affected populations unaware of available assistance and how to access it. A participatory and consultation approach is required to allow communities to articulate their needs, preferences, and influence decision-making in designing dignified community-based responses. IDPs are often unfamiliar with available complaints and feedback channels, leading to their voices being unheard. An interagency Complaints and Feedback Mechanism (CFM) can support the timely sharing of information, interagency referral of complaints, and resolution of cases, ensuring coordinated approaches for PSEA, disability inclusion, and gender mainstreaming. Generating and using evidence-based information will improve response and quality programming, addressing the complex and multifaceted challenges faced by women, girls, children and other at-risk/marginalized/vulnerable groups in Sudan.

The severe food insecurity and water scarcity plaguing Sudan are having devastating effects on the lives of women, girls, and children, exacerbating the already dire humanitarian situation. Women and girls, disproportionately impacted by the ongoing conflict, face heightened risks of exploitation and abuse, and the looming threat of famine only compounds their suffering. With many eating less and last, their vulnerability is significantly increased. High food insecurity is

As families and communities struggle to cope, they often resort to harmful strategies, including rape, intimate partner violence (IPV), child and forced marriage, trafficking, and transactional sex as survival mechanisms. Efforts to access food also can lead to SEA.

Gender disparities in access to resources are pronounced in Sudan. Women and girls are often the last to receive food and essential supplies, which heightens their vulnerability during crises. Gender inequality exacerbates both food insecurity and gender-based violence (GBV), establishing a direct correlation between escalating food insecurity and heightened risks of GBV, disproportionately affecting women and girls. As the famine threat looms, the negative consequences for displaced women and girls intensify. These constraints, framed by inequities between men and women, result in women having less power and access to food production, supplies, and other essential resources related to food.

Women and girls make up the majority of the more than 8.5 million forcibly displaced, with around 150,000 pregnant women unable to access proper care due to two-thirds of health centers not functioning. Displaced women face increased protection and health risks, often resorting to drastic actions such as survival sex or forced marriage. Among the more than 4.86 million people facing acute hunger in Sudan, 1.2 million are pregnant and breastfeeding women suffering from acute malnutrition. In food insecure emergency settings, women and girls eat last and least in their households, leading to 79% of women not meeting their daily minimum dietary requirements. In internally displaced persons (IDP) camps, women and girls have limited access to healthcare, sanitation, and hygiene facilities due to the breakdown of infrastructure. This exacerbates health risks and increases their vulnerability to violence and exploitation. The lack of separate sanitation facilities, lighting, and safe spaces further compounds these risks. Additionally, cultural norms around gender roles and responsibilities shape how shelter and non- food items (NFIs) are used within households, making it crucial to understand and respect these norms for effective programming.

Children's protection and psychosocial well-being are also severely impacted. Families, prioritizing access to food, often divert funds meant for other essential services, leading to increased risks of abuse, exploitation, and neglect. In such scenarios education often becomes a secondary concern many children migrate to cities in search of work, exposing themselves to further risks. The vulnerability of women and girls to these forms of violence could further intensify in the absence of appropriate interventions. Water scarcity forces women and children to walk long distances in search of water, making them prey to armed men. In urban areas, child protection partners report increasing numbers of children begging or providing underpaid casual labor. Women and girls face additional challenges in managing menstrual hygiene due to limited
---
access to essential products like sanitary pads, which hinders their ability to participate in public life, including humanitarian distributions and decision-making processes.

The risks of SEA are amplified during an emergency as actors providing aid exert power, and new actors enter the environment, which presents an opportunity for exploitation and abuse. The SEA Risk Overview (SEARO) Index10 update as of May 2024 assesses Sudan as the sixth out of 34 (6.7) most at-risk of SEA in humanitarian or aid settings. This means that recipients of aid in

Sudan are at a higher risk of SEA by the aid workers. Moreover, in Sudan, remote programming due to the conflict and heavy reliance on new actors, such as NGOs and CBOs, to deliver assistance, who may not have been engaged on PSEA in the past, also increases the risk. For example, staff relocations and turnover affecting GBV/PSEA capacities, all contribute to the increased vulnerability of the affected populations or as the flow of aid continues to increase, new humanitarian actors and staff may not be fully oriented in PSEA and thus underprepared to prevent, mitigate, and even respond to reports.

Sudanese culture is patriarchal, and its hierarchical nature can strengthen pre-existing gender disparities and inequalities and expose crisis affected populations to further risk of SEA. On top of that, factors like shame, discrimination, fear of stigma and retaliation, lack of trust, a culture of silence and family pressure to resolve GBV/SEA incidents through amicable/out-of-court settlement and lack of information have prevented GBV/SEA survivors from seeking the support they require.

Violence against women and girls with disabilities is a critical issue that is related to both gender and disability-based discrimination and exclusion. Put together, these two factors result in an extremely high risk of violence against girls and women with disabilities. Girls with disabilities remain at risk of GBV, comprising rape, SEA. Moreover, the risks of SEA remain high due to widespread economic hardship, driven by increasing prices of basic goods such as food, water, and fuel. The lack of suitable shelter and hunger can heighten the risk of all forms of GBV and SEA for women, girls, and boys, who may engage in survival or transactional sex in exchange for humanitarian aid. Several factors have exponentially increased the risk of SEA. It is worth mentioning that «[w]hile there is not much research available on the prevalence of sexual

Referring to women and girls again, it is also important to underline that as the situation is fluid and families prioritize evacuating them, they are at a higher risk for abuse during their displacement (while seeking out safety and security). With services being down, such as power and phone lines, hotlines may be unreachable to victims/survivors and families willing to report abuses and violations. Additionally, the lack of humanitarian access to affected populations limits protection by presence. The dire economic situation, including lack of liquidity, loss of livelihoods, poverty, food insecurity, lack of or limited humanitarian assistance contribute to the problem as well. The involvement of military personnel in the provision of humanitarian assistance or at border points, disrupted reporting mechanisms, and the breakdown in the rule of

law, formal government reporting channels are affected which will likely impact survivor’s willingness to seek redress and support, all contribute to the increased vulnerability of the affected populations.

Finally, identified project-related risks can include: - Women and girls can face high risks in relation with accessing to cash/ food distribution sites. For instance, traveling long distances to reach the distribution sites for collecting assistance exacerbates targeting, exploitation and harm from non- partner individuals including armed groups/forces and other individuals. - Children may be neglected or exploited, this could involve drop out of school, child labor, early and force marriage, or recruitment into armed groups. - Personnel handling registration and payment including cooperating partner staff and bank staff demonstrate risky and harmful misconduct related to SEA. - Some location of project activities in a humanitarian/conflict-affected environment where rates of GBV are already likely to be high, as increased by the emergency context. - High likelihood that protective services or GBV response options are not fully accessible in some project locations because of insecurity and bad road status during rainy season. - High poverty incidence among refugees, displaced and conflict-affected communities in targeted areas under the project. - Limited capacity and resources, the large scale of the crisis may overwhelm existing humanitarian resources and infrastructure. Moreover, the lack of trained personnel, especially on GBV response and PSEA protocols.

Insufficiency of feedback mechanisms and information channels in place, hinder the ability of the beneficiaries to properly access information and runs the risk of compromising reporting of concerns and violations.

Cross Cluster Collective Actions

Capacity building sessions: Integrated cross-cutting issues mainstreaming sessions focused on AAP, gender equality, disability inclusion and PSEA considerations for humanitarian assistance programming will be conducted with all partners through respective Clusters participating in the Sudan Famine Prevention Plan in coordination with the Protection Cluster. In addition, PSEA Capacity Assessment to be conducted for UN Implementing Partners (IPs). Furthermore, Clusters Coordinators to work with Working Groups and dedicated capacity to identify areas of higher risk.

Needs assessments: Ensure all categories of people are consulted and responded to as appropriate according to their specific needs. Where a needs assessment is undertaken, assessment teams must include women, and should be gender balanced. Enumerators should receive training/orientation on interpersonal communication skills, gender, age, disability sensitivities, PSEA (see Annex I on SEA Risk Mitigation and Annex II on SEA Prevention and Mitigation Checklist), Code of Conduct (CoC), mandatory reporting, referral pathways, and existing complaint and feedback mechanisms.

Conduct community mobilization and outreach activities to raise awareness on child protection, disability risks, GBV and PSEA. Provide information on available services and consult directly with at-risk individuals to ensure they are informed about the accessibility and availability of humanitarian services, and that their concerns and needs are heard. Ensure meaningful inclusion of gender, age, disability, and other forms of diversity by strengthening platforms and opportunities for women, local women's organizations, girls, boys, and PWDs to express their views. Distribute information materials at community sites (spokes) on issues affecting their lives, access
---
4.

8. 9.

to services or assistance, their rights and entitlements, and the CoC for aid actors, including guidance on how to exercise these rights.

Dedicated technical capacity: For inter-Cluster interventions, as well as Cluster and agency-specific level support in reviewing and considering gender, PSEA, disability and inclusion, community engagement and protection elements of assessments, activities and all other relevant Famine Prevention Plan the following Working Groups and dedicated capacity can be utilized: - Accountability to Affected People Working Group - Gender in Humanitarian Action (GiHA) Working Group - Disability and Inclusion Taskforce - Protection Cluster (including GBV sub-Cluster and Child Protection sub-Cluster) - PSEA Network

Collect and analyze disaggregated data by sex, age, and disability (SADDD) to understand the specific needs and vulnerabilities of different groups.

Ensure gender parity of staff for distributions and identify female staff as a contact point for women and girls in the community.

Conduct PSEA training for humanitarian workers, volunteers, and contractors/sub- contractors. Train frontline workers social workers to safely handle disclosures, receive reports, offer support, and safely refer survivors to specialized services. Also, training for PSEA Focal Points and frontline distribution staff on how to refer interagency complaints, and knowledge of internal organizational policy for referral of SEA cases to be conducted.

Ensure your organization have accountability and safeguarding policies/guidelines, including a mandatory PSEA Code of Conduct. All employees and affiliates sign a CoC that clearly demonstrates the zero-tolerance policy for SEA behavior.

Communicate information to be meaningful, timely, reliable, culturally appropriate, gender responsive and easy-to-understand and read across sex, age, and diverse groups. Ensure the provision of safe, timely, reliable, and relevant information and materials that are appropriate, equitable, inclusive, context-specific, and sensitive to cultural and gender considerations. These materials should address issues that impact individuals' lives, their access to services or assistance, their rights, and entitlements, and include guidance on aid actors' Code of Conduct and ways to exercise these rights.

For instance, information on humanitarian interventions to be in structures and languages preferred, trusted, accessible and through different methods (e.g., extension workers, radio, sms messaging, posters, newsletters, television, or loudspeaker), so that information reaches everyone (e.g., literate, illiterate or children).

10. Set up accessible, confidential, and well-understood mechanisms for suggestions and complaints. Mechanisms should be transparent, accessible, safe, easy-to-use and ensure respect of everyone involved and must include both collective and confidential channels. Community-based complaint mechanisms for SEA must be victim-centered, inclusive, and gender and age responsive, in line with the guiding principles of safety, confidentiality, respect, and non-discrimination. It is important that all staff who may receive a SEA complaint receive training on intake, referral, and feedback of SEA incidents (allegations, rumors, and cases), together with GBV and Child Protection sub- Clusters teams and wear forms of identification (i.e., vests, shirts, hats, or similar). Moreover, monitor the effectiveness of handling sensitive complaints and adapt accordingly.

IV.

Key Cluster Recommendations

Food Security and Livelihoods Cluster Ensure the active participation of women, girls and other at-risk groups in all food security, agricultural and nutrition assessment processes. Assess and identify potential SEA risks at the food distribution centres/sites. Ensure that female and child-headed households, other at-risk groups and small-scale producers and traders are identified and targeted for food assistance, including in-kind and agricultural inputs distribution and cash-based transfers. Women and girls, including older women, pregnant and nursing women, and girls, in all household types should be targeted by malnutrition prevention and response initiatives. Food distributions, and emergency agricultural support should not put women and girls at additional risks, including long journeys to and from distribution points. Therefore, it is paramount that specific protection vulnerabilities that affect their exposure to food insecurity and GBV be taken into consideration.
---
Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Cluster ● Enhancement of WASH service providers and frontline worker’s capacities in GBV/SEA prevention, risk mitigation, reporting, and response. ● Identify any protection risks associated with WASH facilities, e.g., sexual assault and sexual abuse of women, girls and boys around water points, latrines and bathing facilities, potential for injury of people with disability or older people around wet areas. For instance, responses need to be careful not to increase protection risks. E.g., bathing facilities and latrines without lights and locks can put women and children at risk of sexual abuse. ● Consider the distance and the route that women and girls must cover to collect water if distributing water. This has implications in terms of a time burden and potential protection risks if it becomes known that they regularly take that route unaccompanied. ● Creation of any new facilities to promote hygiene in the community should be developed in consultation with women, girls, men, and boys in the community. Locations should be accessible to all especially to older women, women, and girls with disabilities, to reduce risk of GBV in accessing these facilities. ● Regulate and timetable water distributions to avoid large groups congregating to prevent viral spread. ● Distribute soap and sanitizer products through community mobilization initiatives. Ensure women are included as recipients and in the distribution process. ● Understanding the respective needs of women, girls, men, and boys helps promote access to, and the appropriate use of, facilities. For example, WASH facilities that are adequately designed with privacy and safety measures (including segregation, locks, adequate lighting) increase the acceptability of the facilities for women and girls to use them. Facilities specifically designed for younger girls and boys, i.e., with a smaller toilet bowl and lower washbasin, also encourage use. ● Provide clear information to communities explaining that beneficiaries, particularly women and girls, do not have to pay or provide services or favours in exchange for water or WASH services. ● Use inputs and feedback from women, girls, men, and boys in a participatory manner to increase hygiene and encourage measures such as handwashing in ways that

resonate with the community. Utilize women and girls’ potential in community mobilization and hygiene promotion.
---
Health Cluster ● Assess and identify potential SEA risks at the health facilities. ● Ensure that all data gathered is sex, age, and disability disaggregated (SADDD), as well as pregnancy status. ● Provide community messaging that pregnant women and girls should continue with their natal care and seek out assisted deliveries. Such messaging should also advise them on precautionary measures they must take relating to their pregnancy; explain that beneficiaries, particularly women and girls, do not have to pay or provide services or favours in exchange for health nutrition assistance. These messages should be conveyed by health care workers and social mobilizers. ● Dignity for patients attending treatment centers must be maintained - particularly for women and girls with separate ablutions, toilets, and privacy screens as well as safe disposal bins for used sanitary items.

When access to health care is negotiated (specifically in negotiations with countries hosting refugees), ensure that referral pathways and access also meet the specific needs and priorities of women and girls. Facilitate the development and dissemination of targeted messaging on preventive, protective and care-seeking behaviors and on available health resources responsive to the different contexts and concerns of women, men, boys, and girls. Provision of the Minimum Initial Service Package (MISP) service package should be adhered to as the minimum standards for Sexual Reproductive Health (SRH) provision.

Nutrition Cluster ● Consult with at-risk groups about ways to minimise safety risks associated with health and nutrition services, e.g., safe locations and routes to health facilities, providing accessibility features at facilities for people with disability (such as handrails and ramps). ● Monitor the nutritional status and needs of women, girls, men, boys, such as rates of malnutrition among children under five, pregnant and breastfeeding women, adolescent girls, and older men and women. ● Ensure the participation of women, men, boys, and girls in the planning of interventions to accurately reflect their unique perspectives, requirements, and challenges in access activities. ● Provide information to communities explaining that beneficiaries, particularly women and girls, do not have to pay or provide services or favours in exchange for health assistance.
---
Prioritize breastfeeding promotion, complementary feeding, and management of acute malnutrition for pregnant and breastfeeds women and girls. Provide pregnant and breastfeeding women and girls with supplementary feeding programs to address increased nutritional needs. Address specific nutritional deficiencies and provide education on nutrition. Ensure that older men and women have access to nutritious food that meets their specific dietary requirements. Consider the safety of accessing nutrition services, particularly for women and girls, to prevent exposure to GBV.

Shelter/Non-Food Items Cluster ● Assess protection, including GBV/SEA risks in shelter and NFI interventions. E.g., a lack of access to shelter causing community tension or conflict; poor or crowded evacuation centres leading to a risk of women, girls or boys experiencing GBV, including the risks of SEA. ● Consult directly with vulnerable people to make sure their concerns and needs are heard, e.g., create and strengthen platforms for women, girls and boys, and people with disability to speak for themselves (provision of ramps and handrails for people with disability). ● Involve people with different disabilities to check that the shelter/ building is truly accessible. ● Consult with at-risk groups about ways to increase safety for shelter and NFI distributions and building activities, e.g., safe locations and routes to distribution sites; timing of distributions during daylight hours; priority queues for at-risk people; safety patrols; accessibility features at distribution sites. ● Assess the shelter needs of vulnerable community members by sex, age, and disability, and prioritize these (e.g., include women and child heads of households, and children with disability). ● Community mobilization, risk communication and surveillance mechanisms for shelter locations should be localized with women taking a leadership role in their design and implementation. ● Specific focus on the protection of female-headed households, older people, and those with pre-existing conditions from SEA must be included in all housing rights and tenure security initiatives. Where appropriate, a moratorium on eviction and rental support interventions should be considered. ● Installation of additional WASH resources in densely populated areas must consider safety and protection concerns for women and girls. Locks, lighting, accessibility, and sex-segregation must be integral to their design.
---
The provision of NFIs must include adequate supplies and dispersal of dignity kits, sanitary materials and other materials related to reproductive health that are culturally appropriate. The selected items for the dignity kits should be based on a participatory consultation with women and girls to ensure their specific and distinct needs and requirements are addressed. Distribution should be accompanied with sensitization on the safe disposal of sanitary supplies/materials to counter potential increased stigma and sanitation issues around menstruation. Any changes in times or locations of distribution of NFIs should be implemented only after consultation with women, men, girls, and boys in the community. In some areas, women may predominantly be responsible for collection, and it is critical that alternate locations and times are accessible for women and do not further increase their burden.

Site Management ● Ensure site planning and management is culturally appropriate. ● Consult with the affected population with engagement of adolescent girls, women (e.g., single, or widowed women), children (e.g., single girl-headed households) and PWDs (e.g., women and girls with disabilities) on site planning and management and consider the specific risks faced by these individuals. ● Demonstrate high quality coordination during site planning management with cross- cutting actors to protect women and girls from GBV, SEA risks. ● Engage with the affected population to establish accessible and safe CFM including SEA reporting channels. ● Any re-planning of sites and accommodation of individuals must consider protection and rights of women and girls – including segregated and safe WASH facilities, lighting, accommodation for single women and men, female-headed households, child-headed households, and separated children. ● Site community engagement must include representation of women a

Purpose

This Checklist is designed to be used for the assessment/observation of interventions to identify, prevent, and mitigate potential SEA and SEA risks in field activities, including cluster response activities in Sudan. The ‘Checklist’ includes basic recommendations on measures to take to mitigate SEA risks.

The tool has individual sections for different types of sector activities: (I) Food/Hygiene/Basic Assistance In-Kind Distribution, (II) Shelter/Non-Food Items (NFIs), (III) Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), (IV) Health, (V) Education Observational, (VI) Protection, (VII) Cash-Based Interventions, (VIII) Camp management, and (IX) General Observations and Additional Comments. Organizations can review these sections, select and use the ones that are relevant for their projects and programme activities.

Who Should Administer the Tool?

The tool can be administered by field staff who observe a particular field activity, review the existence/absence of indicators and mark them in the Checklist. It can be used as a physical document or in an online survey format through tools such as Kobo. While any field staff can use the Checklist, some Organizations opt to use Monitoring &Evaluation (M&E) or Third-Party Monitoring (TPM) field enumerators to administer the tool as part of already existing, ongoing M&E activities. It is essential that staff administering the tool receive training about gender, gender-based violence (GBV), PSEA and referrals, and understand the purpose of the tool and how it is supposed to be applied.

How Should the Tool be Used?

When utilized in the programme design stage, use of the tool involves review of the Checklist by the programme manager/coordinator to identify any gaps and risks in the current design. When utilized in field implementation and monitoring, the tool is used by field staff observing a field activity and noting their observations of the indicators included in the Checklist. Regardless of which area of programming it is used, the tool is intended to result in actions to fill gaps and mitigate identified risks. The results of the Checklist should be used to strengthen PSEA mainstreaming in programme design and implementation, and recommendations and actions can be tracked by the Organization.

Some examples of activities and sites where the field Checklist is applied are : Food/Hygiene/Basic distribution, shelter/NFI/Cash-Based distribution, health clinics, WASH/educational/camp activities and community centres, health clinics. Enumerators may need to clarify some issues with field staff delivering the activity on-site, but the Checklist should never be applied in a survey interview or question and answer-based format. Staff should administer the tool by visiting the field activity while it is ongoing. Programme managers and PSEA Focal Points (hereafter FPs) are recommended to coordinate observation plans together by identifying field activities to be observed, as well as dates, locations and staff who will carry out the observation. It is recommended that an Organization carry out this observation for all their field activities and ongoing projects, and if feasible, at all locations. If it is not possible to carry out observations at all locations, the Agency may select a sample size of locations or use locations and sample sizes already in use by M&E teams. Other staff at the site should be informed and prepared for the arrival of the staff member for observation, and the observer should be permitted to observe the activity while it occurs. During the observation, the observer will go through the Checklist and mark whether they observe the presence or absence of each indicator. If an indicator is not applicable to their context and/or activity, they can mark “not applicable” or “N/A”.

Frequency of application is up to the preference and capacity of each Organization. It is recommended that it be applied at least once during a project cycle. In the case of identified gaps/challenges, the exercise should be repeated to assess whether previously identified gaps/risks have been addressed. Some Organizations also opt to integrate indicators from the Checklist into related M&E activities and therefore apply the Checklist within the context of ongoing, regular M&E schedules.

How Should the Data be Analyzed? The relevant programme managers and PSEA FPs should review the results of the observation(s) together to: a) Identify gaps and risks (through applying the tool); b) Brainstorm actions/solutions to fill the identified gaps and/or mitigate the risks; c) Implement the action plan and initiate relevant changes; d) Track the actions taken to resolve and mitigate identified risks/issues Action points will be based on the types of issues being identified through this observation activity. Some gaps and risks might be very easy to address. For example, if distribution

sites are missing PSEA awareness raising materials and complaint hotline numbers are not visible to beneficiaries, this can easily and quickly be resolved through the dissemination of materials made available by the PSEA Network. Other types of gaps or risks may require more time or decision making that involves the Head of office (HoO), re-alignment/adjustment of budgets, etc. For example, if there is an absence of oversight by humanitarian staff or female humanitarian staff in some activities, staff allocation may need to be reviewed to ensure that activities do not continue unmonitored, or the Agency may need to hire more female staff to fill the gaps. In other cases where a field activity is implemented by contractors or local companies, a review of procedures relating to those companies and their staff may be needed by Human Resources (HR). SEA prevention and mitigation is an ongoing process, so Agencies should take timely corrective actions as feasible, while continuing to work on any longer-term issues that require more time and effort.

Safety & Ethical Considerations

Field observers who will administer should be prepared and understand how to use the tool. It should clearly be communicated that the tool is observational. There are also safety and ethical considerations depending on the type of staff administering the tool. Staff who have never been exposed to protection, GBV and PSEA related topics must be trained on gender, gender-based violence (GBV), and PSEA prior to observation. This training should be provided by the Agencies’ PSEA Focal Point(s) or those who have been directly trained by the PSEA Focal Point.

Reminder:

Observers should be equipped with a PSEA Inter-Agency reporting hotline (if available), organizational reporting hotline or other safe, confidential, accessible, disability-inclusive, child- friendly, responsive and multi-channel effective and high-quality complaints and feedback mechanisms in case they encounter a violation / misconduct that must be reported.

N.B:

The Sudan PSEA Network is available to provide additional technical assistance and support in helping to address identified gaps/risks.
